job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Columbia definitely pays the most to research staff relative to the rest of NYC. Competitive pay to comfortably sustain living in the city. Benefits are great, childcare, higher education subsidized, union position. There's amazing diversity within Columbia, many POC and women leading higher positions.
cons: It really depends on the work ethic and personality principal investigator. It reflects and trickles down to the study coordinator and research staff. Some studies can be incredibly rigid. The department management can be incredibly frustrating and not very helpful. My study had to move 3 different office spaces to make room for other teams all while conducting research at the same time.

job_title: Tech Support in New York, NY
pros: Everyone's experience is different. My experience with the university has been pretty good overall. Been with them for over a year. There is a lot of opportunity to learn. My experience with colleagues and senior management has been positive. Their expectation is to work you hard but I feel that hard work is recognized and appreciated.
cons: Projects and initiatives are sometimes placed on hold based on committee approval.All that hard work may proverbially stay on the shelf as a result. One could argue that many companies and institutions do the same thing.

review_title: Good work if you can get it

job_title: Systems Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Great people in general, an amazing University, and some of the most state of the art research being done in academia.
cons: Co-workers who are uninformed, don't listen, or take informed advice about getting tasks accomplished. A strong desire for the heads of Dept. to "get ahead" versus working with their Department cohorts. Absent leadership that "check in" just for the sake of checking a box with zero follow through. An extremely slow on boarding process A network of individuals who don't communicate their expectations or desires inline with what professional tools are made available to work with. An IT department who continually fail to work with other departments. In essence if it doesn't feel right, abort mission, stay away, and avoid at all costs...even if it looks like a "good fit" at first.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
- Top notch research
- Generally happy work environment at Zuckerman Institute
- Good balance of experimental/theoretical PIs who collaborate well
- Excellent professional support e.g. grant writing, networking with famous professors
- Generally friendly administration
- Easy to walk or take public transit to work
cons:
- Postdoc housing is a scam, don't count on it
- Even if you get postdoc housing, they give you very short notice to find a place and then kick you out after 3 years
- Pay is much too low for NYC cost of living, expect a low quality of life and do not plan to have kids as a postdoc unless your family is rich
- Crappy benefits e.g. expensive health insurance that doesn't cover anything, no retirement benefits, limited support for finding and affording childcare, useless support for finding housing
- Significant hidden costs, e.g. NYC city tax costs ~$2000/year just to live here, food is very overpriced in NYC
- Postdocs are unionized, but the union is not very effective, e.g. raises are 2.5%/year which is less than inflation
- This poor compensation feels very exploitative for such a wealthy university e.g. President Bollinger makes $4.6 million/year and Columbia is the 2nd largest land owner in Manhattan

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
- Amazing benefits and time off; the best vacation policy and medical/dental coverage I've ever had in my life; amazing 401k matching
- Some of your colleagues are simply amazing
- Culture and colleagues vary by the institute or school you're working at, but the more liberal arts schools tend to be more fun!
- Great continuing ed policy and reimbursement for those eligible - take advantage!
cons:
- Promotions are tied to pay increases and vice versa so if you want a pay increase, that has to come with a change in your title, which is difficult to come by, no matter how long you've been there
- The University is trying to streamline and centralize things with a one size fits all policy, leading to gaps in direction from leadership and policy
- Tenured faculty are a pain to work with, but valued more by the University with far superior benefits
- Glaring lack of ethnic diversity in core leadership which trickles down on policy that affects students and staff the most

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: The people I worked with were among the most talented colleagues I've had. I really enjoyed their competency and ability to deliver high quality deliverables and outcomes. I also loved being surrounded by ideas and opportunities to learn about new topics from the world's top experts. Working at a place like Columbia allows you to do high-profile work at a high level, which is exciting. Also, there were a broad array of benefits.
cons:
Higher education can be very political. Whom you are aligned with can matter more than how well you are able to contribute--this can lend itself to a tribal-like thinking that is demotivating and difficult to navigate. I found Columbia to be similar to other higher education institutions in this way. 

Also, when I worked there, some of the top leadership was against working remotely. Columbia is very decentralized, so how this played out depended on what unit or school you worked in and the type of work you did. For me, the inflexibility of some leaders on the topic was disappointing.

The health benefits are good (by US standards), and the 21 vacation days + 3 personal days + unlimited sick days are a plus too. Depending on your manager, work/life balance is also good. I am rarely expected to work outside of normal business hours.
cons: It is nearly IMPOSSIBLE to get a promotion, much less a raise, at Columbia. HR will look for literally any loophole to disqualify a case for salary adjustment. If upward mobility and increasing your earning potential is important to you, I don't recommend Columbia as an employer. The business processes are also antiquated and frustratingly slow and unproductive.

review_title: Great Place to Learn and Carry Out Research
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in New York, NY
pros: Wide selection of good advisers to do a variety of research. Many interdisciplinary groups for a collaborative research environment. Lots of shared equipment facilities for access to many characterization techniques. Plenty to do on- and off-campus when not in the lab. Subsidized housing for students makes it easier to live off of given salary/stipend.
cons: Quality of advisers and teaching style can vary and group selection method isn't ideal. Can be a bit of a high-pressure work environment. Certain social events recently removed (right before pandemic began), so may impact post-pandemic work environment. University hasn't recognized union of graduate student workers which means that working conditions, benefits, etc. are subject to unforeseeable change going forward.

review_title: Not the worst place you could work, but far from the best
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
*Decent benefits and vacation days for just starting out.
*Get to work with the kinds of people that are attracted to a place like Columbia
*If you like cold rooms in the summer, the air conditioners installed are far too large for the spaces they're supposed to cool (when they're working, anyway).
cons:
*Compensation is typically in the bottom 10% based on conversations with my coworkers and a little research- and that's BEFORE taking into account the cost of living.
*You can expect some bureaucracy anywhere, but it's inexplicably bad here. Administrative positions multiply like mold, while budgets that affect the classrooms haven't grown in the better part of a decade. Less than 5% of the full-time tenured faculty in our department have interacted with President Bollinger for any length of time.
*There is zero accountability, which is frustrating if you want something done correctly or for people to do the right thing. Expect an extreme amount of office politics and higher than usual turnover from faculty and staff that get fed up- unfortunately that leads to the people who want to do the right thing leaving, sticking you with a high concentration of people causing problems. I have only seen one workplace with a higher level of dysfunction, and it's unfortunately also affiliated with Columbia. 
*The tuition benefit that supposedly makes taking classes free doesn't- expect so many university fees that it's comparable to going to a community college. On the bright side your department will probably be so understaffed that you don't have time to take any classes.

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission, excellent school, trial by fire learning - tough environment enables you to think quickly and handle stress, many of the people here are great. With a masters degree and good networking, you can build a life here. The executive masters programs are the best, cost more, but provide more support and resources than part time programs.
cons: If you're highly ambitious, you will not find this a good working environment. As an administrator you will be limited by salary and upward mobility. if you don't have a masters degree (but you can apply to get on through several programs here). However the tuition benefit has been cut, it used to be 3 classes per semester in a degree program and now it is 2 classes and 65% of each additional class, so it may still cost thousands of dollars / semester. Even as an admin if you make $110K it's still not enough to compensate for the amount of work and stress you go through. Some departments lack any form of transparency and many people are not solution oriented or well trained (grants management, especially) so you will find that highly frustrating. Very bureaucratic environment - can be toxic.
